Example

A local authority has flood control plans in which the emergency and rescue services are alerted when the river level rises to critical values. A linear model is used to estimate the variation of height with time. After a period of continuous heavy rain the level one day was \(1.5 \, \textrm{m}\) at \(8\) a.m. and \(1.8 \, \textrm{m}\) at \(2\) p.m.

  1. Use a linear model to write down an equation for estimating the level of the river at different times of the day:
  2. Suggest a suitable range of values of time for which the model could be used:
  3. What time does the model predict that the level of the river will reach \( 2 \, \textrm{m}\)?

Solution

  1. If the level of water is represented by \(L \, \textrm{m}\) and time by \(t\) hours after \(8\) a.m. then a linear model for the level as a function of time may be written

    \( \quad L = at + b\)

    where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants to be found from the other information in the problem. Specifically, it is stated that \(L = 1.5\) when \(t = 0\) and \(L = 1.8\) when \(t = 6.\) The first statement implies that

    \(\quad 1.5 = 0 + b \quad \textrm{or} \quad b = 1.5\)

    The second statement implies that

    \(\quad 1.8 = 6a + b\)

    or, after substituting for \(b,\)

    \(\quad 1.8 = 6a + 1.5 \quad \textrm{or} \quad 0.3 = 6a \quad \textrm{or} \quad a = 0.05\)

    So the equation for estimating the level of the river at different times is

    \(\quad L = 0.05t + 1.5\)

  2. The model is valid between \(8\) a.m. and \(2\) p.m. and, subsequently, only as long as the river level rises steadily.

  3. The model will predict a level of \(2 \, \textrm{m}\) at time \(t\) given by

    \( \quad 2 = 0.05t + 1.5 \quad \textrm{or} \quad t =\dfrac{0.5}{0.05}= 10\)

    i.e. \(10\) hours after \(8\) a.m. which is \(6\) p.m.

Example

During one winter, the roads in a rural area were completely free from snow when it started snowing at midnight. It snowed heavily all night and day. By \(10\) a.m. it was \(19 \, \textrm{cm}\) deep.

To save money the local authorities wait until the snow is \(30 \, \textrm{cm}\) deep before ploughing the snow away from the roads. Forecast when ploughing should start, stating any assumptions you have made.

Solution

If the depth of snow is represented by \(D \, \textrm{cm}\) and time by \(t\) hours after midnight then a linear modelfor the depth as a function of time may be written:

\(\quad D = at + b\)

where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants to be found from the other information in the problem or from assumptions. As there was no snow at midnight

\(quad 0 = 0 + b \quad \textrm{or} \quad \(b = 0\)

It is stated that \(D = 19\) when \(t = 10\), i.e.

\(\quad 19 = 10a \quad \textrm{or} \quad a = 1.9\)

So the equation for estimating the depth of snow at different times is

\( \quad D = 1.9t\)

The model will predict a level of \(30 \, \textrm{cm}\) at a time \(t\) is given by

\( \quad 30 = 1.9t \quad \textrm{or} \quad t =\dfrac{30}{1.9}= 15.789\)

i.e. \(15.789\) hours after midnight which is a little after \(3.47\) p.m.

Assuming that the snow build up is steady e.g. no drifting or change in precipitation, this suggests that ploughing should start about \(3.45\) p.m.
